abstract.p: Lloyd Jaconson letter, commenting on July 21 article, says Mayor Rudolph Giuliani's consideration of ban on alcohol sales at outdoor street festivals and fairs is neither unique nor radical

block.p: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's consideration of a ban on alcohol sales at outdoor street festivals and fairs (news article, July 21) is neither unique nor radical. Many other cities across the country have already adopted similar measures to prevent outbursts of alcohol-fueled lawlessness, as well as to create a safer environment for all revelers.

Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's consideration of a ban on alcohol sales at outdoor street festivals and fairs (news article, July 21) is neither unique nor radical. Many other cities across the country have already adopted similar measures to prevent outbursts of alcohol-fueled lawlessness, as well as to create a safer environment for all revelers.

In Washington, a National Parks Service ban on alcohol has led to noticeable reductions in the number of assaults and arrests, and has even helped cut down on the time and expense of cleanup after events.

Short of a total ban on alcohol at street festivals, New York City could put other restrictions into effect: limit the number of drinks per consumer; limit the size of drink cups; screen out under-age attendees; or separate drinking areas from family-friendly zones.
The writer is alcohol policies advocate, Center for Science in the Public Interest.
